metadata.titleEn: HiWATER: 1km/5day compositing Leaf Area Index (LAI) product of the Heihe River Basin (2010-2014)
metadata.description: The 1 km / 5-day Lai data set of Heihe River basin provides the 5-day Lai synthesis results of 2010-2014. The data uses Terra / MODIS, Aqua / MODIS, as well as domestic satellites fy3a / MERSI and fy3b / MERSI sensor data to build a multi-source remote sensing data set with a spatial resolution of 1 km and a time resolution of 5 days. Multi-source remote sensing data sets can provide more angles and more observations than a single sensor in a limited time. However, due to the difference of on orbit running time and performance of sensors, the observation quality of multi-source data sets is uneven. Therefore, in order to make more effective use of multi-source data sets, the algorithm first classifies the quality of multi-source data sets, which can be divided into first level data, second level data and third level data according to the observation rationality. The third level data are observations polluted by thin clouds and are not used for calculation. The purpose of quality evaluation and classification is to provide the basis for the selection of the optimal data set and the design of inversion algorithm flow. Leaf area index product inversion algorithm is designed to distinguish mountain land and vegetation type, using different neural network inversion model. Based on global DEM map and surface classification map, PROSAIL model is used for continuous vegetation such as grassland and crops, and gost model is used for forest and mountain vegetation. Using the reference map generated by the measured ground data of the forests in the upper reaches of Heihe River and the oasis in the middle reaches, and scaling up the corresponding high-resolution reference map to 1km resolution, compared with the Lai product, the product has a good correlation between the farmland and the forest area and the reference value, and the overall accuracy basically meets the accuracy threshold of 0.5%, 20% specified by GCOS. By cross comparing this product with Lais products such as MODIS, geov1 and glass, the accuracy of this Lai product is better than that of similar products compared with reference value. In a word, the synthetic Lai data set of 1km / 5 days in Heihe River Basin comprehensively uses multi-source remote sensing data to improve the estimation accuracy and time resolution of Lai parameter products, so as to better serve the application of remote sensing data products.

background: Upscaling of eco-hydrological processes on a heterogeneous surface is a grand challenge. Progress in this field is hindered by the poor availability of multiscale observations. HiWATER is an experiment designed to address this challenge through instrumentation on hierarchically nested scales to obtain multiscale and multidisciplinary data.
challenges: Progress in this field is hindered by the poor availability of multiscale observations.
methods: Several intensive observation periods (IOPs) and continuous hydrometeorological observations were carried out during HiWATER. Only data collected during the IOP in 2012 are presented in this paper. Instruments for the oasis-desert system were arranged in hierarchically nested scales to capture multi-scale eco-hydrological processes. We established a sparse network to investigate the oasis-desert interaction. One superstation was constructed within the oasis, and four EC towers and four two-layer automatic meteorological stations (AMSs) were installed in different landscapes surrounding the oasis, including sandy desert, desert pavement, desert steppe, and wetland. Intensive observations were implemented at the irrigation district scale. A total of 12 airborne remote sensing missions were conducted to cover the FEA using LiDAR, an imaging spectrometer, a multi-angle thermal imager, and an L-band microwave radiometer.
dataset: We introduce a multiscale dataset obtained from Heihe Watershed Allied Telemetry Experimental Research (HiWATER) in an oasis-desert area in 2012. The HiWATER observation system consists of a flux observation matrix of eddy covariance towers, large aperture scintillometers, and automatic meteorological stations; an eco-hydrological sensor network of soil moisture and leaf area index; hyper-resolution airborne remote sensing using LiDAR, imaging spectrometer, multi-angle thermal imager, and L-band microwave radiometer; and synchronical ground measurements of vegetation dynamics and photosynthesis processes. All observational data were carefully quality controlled throughout sensor calibration, data collection, data processing, and datasets generation. The data are freely available at figshare and the Cold and Arid Regions Science Data Centre.

background: The Earth’s surface radiation budget is an essential parameter for estimation of the surface energy budget and is used for various applications, including weather prediction, monitoring and analysis of climate, and terrestrial ecological and hydrological systems. As a particularly important component of the surface radiation budget, surface solar irradiance (SSI) is the primary source of energy for the Earth’s surface; it controls the total energy exchange between the atmosphere and the land‐ocean surface and also serves as a key driving force for evapotranspiration, plant growth, and related processes. SSI data with large geographical coverage (up to global) and high spatiotemporal resolution can be obtained from satellite data. Estimating the surface solar radiation using satellite remote sensing techniques is essential not only for complementing the sparse network of surface station measurements, but also for verifying climate model output and reanalysis data.
research objective: In this paper, a new satellite‐derived approach for obtaining instantaneous surface solar irradiance (SSI) by combining Moderate Resolution Imaging Spectroradiometer (MODIS) and Multifunctional Transport Satellite (MTSAT) data is presented and validated using one year pyranometer measurements from five stations in northern China.
challenges: However, in mountainous areas the results need further refinement.
methods: Here we use MTSAT data to capture the changes of cloud fields in the atmosphere and use MODIS products to obtain the dynamic aerosol loading, water vapor content, surface reflectance, and other information. Meanwhile, on the basis of instantaneous retrieval results, the calculation of hourly average SSI is also explored.
dataset: Two types of satellite data were used in this study: polar‐orbiting satellite products from multispectral MODIS, and geostationary meteorological satellite data from the Multifunctional Transport Satellite MTSAT1R. The pyranometer data for validation come from five meteorological stations where the SSI is measured alongside other meteorological parameters. These stations are the Guantao and Daxing experimental stations in north China and the Yingke oasis station, Huazhaizi desert station, and A’rou freeze‐thaw observation station in northwest China.
findings: The preliminary validation demonstrates that both instantaneous and hourly SSIs can be produced accurately over northern China using this approach, and the retrieval quality of hourly SSI data is slightly better than that of instantaneous SSI data.

Definition.Question: How is the quality of a multi-source remote sensing dataset evaluated and classified?
Definition.Answer: The quality of a multi-source remote sensing dataset is evaluated and classified based on the observation's reasonableness and performance differences among sensors. The data is categorized into different quality levels, such as primary, secondary, and tertiary data, where tertiary data is affected by thin cloud contamination and not used in calculations. This classification aids in selecting the optimal dataset for parameter retrieval algorithms.

Comparison.Question: What are the similarities and differences between the multiscale dataset from Heihe Watershed Allied Telemetry Experimental Research (HiWATER) and traditional hydrometeorological datasets?
Comparison.Answer: The multiscale dataset from HiWATER incorporates a hierarchical observation system with instruments like eddy covariance towers, LiDAR, and imaging spectrometers, capturing detailed eco-hydrological processes at various scales. Traditional hydrometeorological datasets may not have the same hierarchical structure and often lack the integration of high-resolution airborne remote sensing data. Both types aim to provide comprehensive environmental data, but HiWATER's dataset is specifically designed for multiscale and multidisciplinary coverage, addressing challenges in eco-hydrological process upscaling.

Comparison.Question: How do the challenges in capturing surface solar irradiance (SSI) data using satellite remote sensing compare to those faced when using ground-based pyranometer measurements?
Comparison.Answer: Capturing surface solar irradiance (SSI) using satellite remote sensing offers extensive geographical coverage and high spatiotemporal resolution, which is not achievable with ground-based pyranometers that provide point-specific measurements. However, satellite methods face challenges in mountainous areas where results require refinement. Ground-based pyranometer measurements are limited by their sparse network but are crucial for validating satellite-derived data. Both methods aim to accurately estimate surface solar radiation but encounter different technical and environmental challenges.

Interpretation.Question: How do multi-source remote sensing techniques enhance the estimation accuracy and temporal resolution of eco-hydrological parameters in heterogeneous landscapes?
Interpretation.Answer: Multi-source remote sensing techniques enhance the estimation accuracy and temporal resolution by utilizing data from various sensors such as Terra/MODIS, Aqua/MODIS, and FY3A/MERSI, constructing a dataset with a spatial resolution of 1km and a temporal resolution of 5 days. These techniques provide more angles and frequent observations compared to a single sensor, allowing for a comprehensive synthesis of data. Quality grading of observations ensures the selection of optimal datasets for leaf area index (LAI) inversion, improving the parameter accuracy.

Interpretation.Question: What are the challenges of capturing eco-hydrological processes on a heterogeneous surface, and how can hierarchically nested instrumentation designs address these challenges?
Interpretation.Answer: The challenges include the poor availability of multiscale observations, which hinder the progress in upscaling eco-hydrological processes. Hierarchically nested instrumentation designs, such as those implemented in the HiWATER experiment, address these challenges by deploying instruments at multiple scales to capture diverse eco-hydrological processes. This includes a sparse network for oasis-desert interactions and a superstation within the oasis, supplemented by environmental sensors and remote sensing missions, providing comprehensive data coverage.

Interpretation.Question: What methodologies are effective in using satellite-derived data to estimate surface solar irradiance (SSI) and refine results in complex terrains?
Interpretation.Answer: Effective methodologies involve combining data from polar-orbiting satellites like MODIS and geostationary satellites like MTSAT. This approach captures atmospheric changes, aerosol loading, and surface reflectance. Validation against pyranometer measurements ensures accuracy, while the refinement of results, especially in mountainous areas, may require further methodology adjustments to account for terrain-specific factors affecting SSI estimation.

Causal Antecedent.Answer: The variability in observation quality among different sensors used in data collection for eco-hydrological studies is primarily due to differences in the sensors' operational times and performance capabilities while in orbit.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is it crucial to implement intensive observation periods and continuous hydrometeorological observations in eco-hydrological research?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Intensive observation periods and continuous hydrometeorological observations are crucial to ensure the capture of multi-scale eco-hydrological processes, especially in heterogeneous surfaces like oasis-desert systems, where sparse networks and superstations are strategically placed to gather comprehensive data.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the challenges of accurately estimating surface solar irradiance (SSI) in mountainous areas using satellite data?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The challenges of accurately estimating surface solar irradiance (SSI) in mountainous areas using satellite data arise due to the complex terrain, which affects cloud field changes and surface reflectance, requiring further refinement in the retrieval techniques.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential outcomes of integrating multi-source remote sensing data in the estimation of leaf area index (LAI) compared to using a single sensor source?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Integrating multi-source remote sensing data can provide more angles and observational opportunities within a limited time, potentially leading to improved estimation accuracy and time resolution of LAI parameters. It allows for better data selection and algorithm design by leveraging quality assessments and classification of data into levels based on observation rationality.

Causal Consequence.Question: What could be the consequences of implementing hierarchically nested scales in instrumentation for eco-hydrological data collection?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Using hierarchically nested scales in instrumentation can capture multi-scale eco-hydrological processes effectively, enabling comprehensive data collection across different landscapes such as oasis, desert, and wetland areas. It helps in understanding interactions within oasis-desert systems and provides detailed data that can be used for various eco-hydrological research purposes.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the possible effects of using satellite remote sensing techniques on estimating surface solar radiation in comparison to traditional surface station measurements?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Satellite remote sensing techniques for estimating surface solar radiation can provide large geographical coverage and high spatiotemporal resolution, complementing the sparse network of surface station measurements. This approach can also aid in verifying climate models and reanalysis data, although it may require refinement in mountainous areas to improve accuracy.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to use multi-source remote sensing data for estimating leaf area index (LAI) in eco-hydrological studies?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Multi-source remote sensing data allows for more comprehensive observations by providing multiple angles and more frequent observations than single-sensor data. This approach helps improve the estimation accuracy and temporal resolution of LAI parameter products, which is crucial for effective application in remote sensing data products.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the purpose of implementing hierarchical instrumentation in the HiWATER experiment?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The hierarchical instrumentation in the HiWATER experiment is designed to capture multiscale and multidisciplinary data, addressing the challenge of upscaling eco-hydrological processes on heterogeneous surfaces and improving the availability of multiscale observations.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What methods are used to ensure the quality and reliability of data collected from multiscale remote sensing platforms for eco-hydrological analysis?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The multiscale dataset obtained from the Heihe Watershed Allied Telemetry Experimental Research (HiWATER) includes a flux observation matrix of eddy covariance towers, large aperture scintillometers, and automatic meteorological stations. Quality control is ensured through sensor calibration, data collection, data processing, and dataset generation, with all observational data being carefully quality controlled throughout these stages.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How are different satellite and ground-based data sources integrated to improve the accuracy of surface solar irradiance (SSI) estimations?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: To estimate SSI, the approach combines Moderate Resolution Imaging Spectroradiometer (MODIS) products for dynamic aerosol loading, water vapor content, and surface reflectance, with changes in cloud fields captured by the Multifunctional Transport Satellite (MTSAT) data. This integration is validated using pyranometer measurements from meteorological stations.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedural steps are involved in constructing a multiscale observation system to study eco-hydrological processes in oasis-desert systems?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: In the HiWATER experiment, the observation system was constructed with a sparse network to investigate oasis-desert interaction, including one superstation in the oasis and multiple eddy covariance towers and automatic meteorological stations in different surrounding landscapes. Additionally, 12 airborne remote sensing missions were conducted using LiDAR, an imaging spectrometer, a multi-angle thermal imager, and an L-band microwave radiometer to cover the field experimental area (FEA).

Enablement.Question: What methodologies allow the integration of multiple satellite data sources to improve the accuracy and temporal resolution of leaf area index (LAI) datasets?
Enablement.Answer: The methodologies involve using data from Terra/MODIS, Aqua/MODIS, FY3A/MERSI, and FY3B/MERSI sensors to construct a multi-source remote sensing dataset with a spatial resolution of 1km and a temporal resolution of 5 days. The data undergo quality grading and the algorithm design includes neural network inversion methods that differentiate between mountain plains and vegetation types using different models.

Enablement.Question: What role does hierarchical instrumentation play in enabling detailed observation of oasis-desert interactions in eco-hydrological studies?
Enablement.Answer: Hierarchical instrumentation, including a sparse network of eddy covariance towers, automatic meteorological stations, and eco-hydrological sensor networks, enables detailed observations by capturing multiscale data. Instruments are arranged to capture interactions between different landscapes, such as oasis, sandy desert, desert pavement, desert steppe, and wetland, facilitating the study of oasis-desert interactions.

Expectation.Question: Why might there be challenges associated with the availability of multiscale observations in eco-hydrological data collection methods?
Expectation.Answer: Progress in the field is hindered by the poor availability of multiscale observations, which can be attributed to the complexity of capturing multi-scale eco-hydrological processes across different landscapes, as demonstrated by the need for hierarchically nested scales and a sparse network of diverse instrumentation.

Judgmental.Question: How would you evaluate the effectiveness of using multiscale and multidisciplinary data collection methods in addressing eco-hydrological challenges in heterogeneous landscapes?
Judgmental.Answer: The use of multiscale and multidisciplinary data collection methods, such as those employed in HiWATER, appears to be an effective approach for addressing eco-hydrological challenges in heterogeneous landscapes. The hierarchical nesting of instruments and the integration of different data types, including eddy covariance towers and airborne remote sensing, allow for a comprehensive understanding of complex eco-hydrological processes across different scales. However, the success of this approach relies heavily on the careful calibration and quality control of all observational data.

Judgmental.Question: In your opinion, what are the potential challenges in achieving high accuracy with satellite-derived datasets for estimating surface solar irradiance (SSI) in mountainous regions?
Judgmental.Answer: Satellite-derived datasets for estimating SSI face challenges in mountainous regions due to complex terrain, which can affect the retrieval of accurate surface reflectance and atmospheric parameters. The approach combining MODIS and MTSAT data shows potential, but further refinement is needed to address these challenges. The dynamic nature of cloud fields and aerosols in mountainous areas may require more sophisticated models and validation efforts using ground-based measurements to improve accuracy.

Judgmental.Question: How do you assess the impact of integrating multiple remote sensing sources on the precision and temporal resolution of leaf area index (LAI) datasets?
Judgmental.Answer: Integrating multiple remote sensing sources significantly enhances the precision and temporal resolution of LAI datasets. By using data from various sensors like Terra/MODIS, Aqua/MODIS, and FY3A/MERSI, a more comprehensive dataset is achieved, providing frequent observations and better spatial coverage. The quality grading and selection of optimal data for LAI retrieval further improve the product's accuracy. This integrated approach allows for more reliable LAI estimates, especially when compared to those derived from single-sensor datasets.

Assertion.Question: I don't understand how multiscale observations can be effectively collected and managed from such a diverse set of environmental conditions in the Heihe River Basin.
Assertion.Answer: The HiWATER experiment addresses the challenge of collecting multiscale observations by using a hierarchically nested scale approach. This includes a range of instruments such as a flux observation matrix of eddy covariance towers, large aperture scintillometers, and automatic meteorological stations, as well as hyper-resolution airborne remote sensing with LiDAR, imaging spectrometer, multi-angle thermal imager, and an L-band microwave radiometer. These tools capture eco-hydrological processes across different landscapes, and careful quality control is applied throughout sensor calibration, data collection, processing, and dataset generation.

Assertion.Question: I'm unsure how the quality of multi-source remote sensing datasets is assessed and maintained, especially when dealing with diverse sensor data.
Assertion.Answer: In the context of the Heihe River Basin LAI data collection, the quality of multi-source remote sensing datasets is assessed by implementing a grading system based on observational rationality. The data are categorized into primary, secondary, and tertiary, with the tertiary data being affected by thin cloud pollution and excluded from calculations. This quality assessment helps in selecting optimal datasets for LAI inversion and guides the design of retrieval algorithms.

Assertion.Question: I can't make sense of how different models are chosen for LAI inversion when dealing with diverse vegetation types and topographies.
Assertion.Answer: For LAI inversion, different models are selected based on the specific characteristics of vegetation types and topography. The PROSAIL model is used for continuous vegetation like grassland and crops, while the slope GOST model is used for forest and mountainous vegetation. This differentiation is informed by a global DEM map and surface classification map, ensuring that the most suitable model is applied for accurate LAI estimation.

Request/Directive.Question: Please summarize the multiscale data collection methods used to address the challenge of upscaling eco-hydrological processes on heterogeneous surfaces.
Request/Directive.Answer: The multiscale data collection methods involve the use of instrumentation on hierarchically nested scales to capture eco-hydrological processes. This includes a flux observation matrix of eddy covariance towers, large aperture scintillometers, automatic meteorological stations, and an eco-hydrological sensor network. Hyper-resolution airborne remote sensing using LiDAR, imaging spectrometer, multi-angle thermal imager, and L-band microwave radiometer is utilized alongside synchronical ground measurements of vegetation dynamics and photosynthesis processes.

Request/Directive.Question: Please analyze the challenges associated with using multiscale remote sensing data for eco-hydrological research in desert-oasis systems.
Request/Directive.Answer: One of the primary challenges is the poor availability of multiscale observations. The observational data's quality can vary due to differences in sensor performance and operational time. Furthermore, in mountainous areas, results from satellite-derived data may require further refinement to improve accuracy.

Request/Directive.Question: Please explore potential datasets available for analyzing surface solar irradiance and how they can be validated using ground-based measurements.
Request/Directive.Answer: Potential datasets for analyzing surface solar irradiance include satellite-derived data from sources like MODIS and MTSAT. These datasets can be validated using pyranometer measurements from meteorological stations, such as those located at Guantao, Daxing, Yingke oasis, Huazhaizi desert, and A’rou freeze-thaw observation stations. The validation process can demonstrate the accuracy of both instantaneous and hourly surface solar irradiance data over northern China.
